title: What do I do if I can't make a 341 trustee hearing?
question: I am on a 6 mth probation at my new job and the trustee hearing is scheduled on a day I have to be in a mandatory training at work (I am a healthcare professional). I was told there is no way the trustee will reschedule. Please advise?
answers:
I am a Florida lawyer but bankruptcy law and procedure is federal and relatively uniform. But there may be variations in procedure from place to place. With that caveat, I will say that you should be able to get your 341 hearing rescheduled. No hearing is so sacrosanct that it cannot be rescheduled.

The problem is in noticing the new date. If you have an attorney he/she has to send out notices to all of the creditors of the new date and time. If you are unrepresented by counsel you probably are not equipped to do that. The trustee isn't going to do it. (That is probably what he/she meant when they said they would not reschedule.) Ordinarily, neither will the clerk of the bankruptcy court send out new notices. They only do it once. But if you are unrepresented there may be special provisions for pro se debtors. Check with the clerk. In fact, that's who you should be dealing with all along, not the trustee. Maybe you can pay an attorney just to help you with the rescheduling.

In San Diego, appearances at 341a meetings are mandatory, as in the debtor 'shall' appear, which is provided in the Bankruptcy Code. That said, it is NOT true that there is NO WAY the trustee will reschedule. Depending on your Trustee and the status of your case (due diligence documents provided, petition and statement of affairs completed in full and as accurate as possible) a one time continuance is usually permitted. You should have your attorney contact the trustee ahead of time, to advise the trustee of the conflict and of the request to continue. If you are self represented, this will fall on your shoulders, and could complicate matters. Having said all this, the continuance would likely only be for a few weeks at most, so if you are looking to try and get outside the 6 month probation period, that may become problematic. All you can do is ask. Failing all of this, if the case is dismissed for failure to appear, in some instances you can move to vacate the dismissal, at further cost, of course. Good Luck. John C. Colwell, Debt Relief Legal Clinic, San Diego, CA

I agree with the answer above. In addition, you should know that the rescheduled date will not be up to your discretion. It will be set by the trustee and probably be about 30 days after the current date. That meeting you cannot miss, unless you want ot jeopardize your discharge.

If you cannot make the first meeting, please inform the trustee (or have your attorney inform the trustee) well in advance.
